Articles.Content:
I was wondering if anyone could help me figure out what I'm missing in my math for an asteroid refinery ship.  The ship has 2 of the large ISRUs. I plan to have them both produce all three of their Lf/Ox options (Lf+Ox, Lf, and Ox) simultaneously for maximum fuel production. The Lf+Ox uses .50 ore/sec, the Lf uses .45 ore/sec, and the Ox uses .55 ore/sec. I add that up to equal that the ISRU uses 1.5 units of ore per second for those three options to run in parallel, x2 for the other, for a total usage of 3 units of ore/sec for both of the ISRUs.  The large drill says it has a max ore output of 1 unit of ore/sec, but I red on the parts description page that I should expect .5 ore/sec as a more dependable figure. So my refinery has 6 of the larger drills.

 

The issue is that when I launch it and use it on my test asteroid,  a class C asteriod with an ore concentration of 90%, once my equipment reaches optimal operating temperatures, I have a net draw on my ore holding tanks of 1.5 units of ore/sec when I should be breaking around even.  It seems to me that if the issue is the ore percentage being around 90%, I should have a net draw of around 10% of total expected output, .3 units of ore/sec instead of the 1.5 units of ore/sec. I've rechecked my system settings, but I can't seem to find where the issue is.

Thoughts?

Moving to Gameplay Questions.

What level engineer do you have on your mining vessel?

First off, sorry for posting in the wrong place.

Secondly, it's a probe ship. So no engineer bonuses. It's really a kerbin orbit test bed for a deep space refinery for Dres-roids. The refinery is fuel cell powered with a pair of rtg's providing basic power supply. 16 large fuel cells, 4 large expanding radiators, and 4 medium expanding radiators power and cool 2 large ISRUs and six large drills. I don't even want to think about how many solar panels it would take to power this thing in Dres orbit.
Um, I think something is off in your drill vs. converter calculation. IIRC, the last time I saw a detailed calculation, it took 16 large drills to produce enough ore to feed one large converter.

1 hour ago, bewing said:

Um, I think something is off in your drill vs. converter calculation. IIRC, the last time I saw a detailed calculation, it took 16 large drills to produce enough ore to feed one large converter.

That seems true for planets, where a rich ore spot is likely to be 10-11%.  Asteroids can be 95%!

Which is why I like using them as a refueling source. My fuel output at max production is enough to fire a poodle at 1/3 full thrust for as long as the ore supply lasts out. That may not sound extremely impressive, but it isn't nothing.

I haven't done asteroid mining (mainly because it requires using the Klaw, which I tend to steer clear of).

However, in general, drills harvest ore faster with higher-level engineers... and if there's no engineer, they harvest a lot slower.  That's certainly true on planets, and I expect it would be true for asteroids as well.

Therefore, if the documentation for a drill is that it's supposed to harvest ore at a certain rate... that number may be "normalized" with the assumption you have an engineer on board.  (I don't actually know that, it's just a guess.)  So perhaps the fact that your drills aren't running fast enough to keep up with the ISRUs could be due to simply not having an engineer on board.

It's a simple experiment-- put an engineer on there and see what happens.

I just never liked the idea of a manned Dres-roid miner. I try to play with a little bit of logic in mind, that you're not going to just send some poor schmuck to go mine asteroids around Dres for years at a time with only a tiny little cockpit to call home. The space enthusiast and sci-fi writer in me just doesn't see manned remote mining rigs anytime in the future.  So I don't build any.

*shrug*
